choices.text: Electroconvulsive therapy can also be given without short general anesthesia
Electroconvulsive therapy can be given without administering a muscle relaxant
Electroconvulsive therapy can be administered to minors
Electroconvulsive therapy can be administered in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Electroconvulsive therapy, keeping in mind the modifications done in the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA) 2017 mandates that ECT must always be administered with anesthesia and muscle relaxants
  • ECT is allowed during pregnancy when clinically indicated and is considered safe
  • ECT in minors is allowed only with Mental Health Review Board approval, not freely administered

Explanation of other options:

Electroconvulsive therapy can also be given without short general anesthesia (Option A): Prohibited under MHCA 2017; anesthesia is mandatory.

Electroconvulsive therapy can be given without administering a muscle relaxant (Option B): Also prohibited; use of a muscle relaxant is mandatory.

Electroconvulsive therapy can be administered in minors (Option C): Permitted only with guardian consent and Mental Health Review Board approval

Key Takeaways:

  • Modified ECT (with anesthesia and muscle relaxants) is mandatory under MHCA 2017
  • ECT is permitted in pregnancy
  • Minors require approval from the Mental Health Review Board before ECT

choices.text: Ladislas Von Meduna
Lucio Bini and Ugo Cerletti
Paracelcus
Paul Greengard

questions.text: The concept of the usage of electricity to produce therapeutic seizures was given by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lucio Bini and Ugo Cerletti introduced the use of electricity to induce therapeutic seizures, leading to the development of Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)
  • Their experiments on animals and subsequent application in humans in 1938 laid the foundation for modern ECT
  • The first patient treated showed remarkable improvement after a series of treatments

Explanation of other options:

Ladislas Von Meduna (Option A): Introduced chemical convulsive therapy using camphor and later pentylenetetrazol, not electricity

Paracelsus (Option C): A Renaissance physician and alchemist, not associated with ECT
Paul Greengard (Option D): Known for work on neurotransmitter signaling, not seizure therapy

Key Takeaways:

  • Bini and Cerletti were pioneers of electrically induced seizures for therapy
  • Their work established the modern foundation of ECT

choices.text: Electroconvulsive therapy is the best step in management
Parenteral administration of lorazepam may help in reversing her current symptoms
Detailed laboratory workup is essential in determining the cause of such symptoms
All the above statements are true

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with a background of chronic schizophrenia presented with complaints of waxy flexibility, episodes of mutism, posturing, and catalepsy for the last 7 days. Which of the following is true regarding her management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with classic features of catatonia (waxy flexibility, mutism, posturing, catalepsy), which can occur in schizophrenia, mood disorders, or due to medical causes
  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is effective and often the treatment of choice, especially in malignant catatonia or when the patient is non-responsive to medication.
  • Lorazepam, especially when administered parenterally, can lead to dramatic improvement and is often used as a diagnostic and therapeutic trial.l
  • A detailed laboratory evaluation is critical to rule out organic or medical causes of catatonia before attributing it solely to psychiatric illness.

Explanation of other options:

Electroconvulsive therapy is the best step in management (Option A): True in severe or refractory catatonia.
Parenteral administration of lorazepam may help in reversing her current symptoms

(Option B): True, commonly used as a first-line treatment.

Detailed laboratory workup is essential in determining the cause of such symptoms

(Option C): True, to rule out organic pathology

Key Takeaways:

  • Catatonia can be psychiatric or medical in origin
  • Lorazepam and ECT are both effective treatments
  • Laboratory evaluation is essential to exclude medical causes

choices.text: Presence of mood-congruent psychotic symptoms
Presence of suicidal ideations or suicidal attempt
Depression with somatic symptoms
Psychomotor agitation

questions.text: In a patient presenting to the clinic with Major Depressive Disorder, Electroconvulsive therapy is least indicated for which of the following clinical presentations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ECT is highly effective in treating severe depression, especially when accompanied by psychotic symptoms, suicidal ideation, refusal to eat, or psychomotor agitation
  • Somatic symptoms (e.g., vague bodily complaints without a medical basis) are more typical of somatization disorder, and patients with somatic presentations are less likely to benefit from ECT.
  • Therefore, ECT is least indicated in patients where somatic symptoms dominate the clinical picture.

Explanation of other options:

Presence of mood-congruent psychotic symptoms (Option A): Common and clear indication for ECT

Presence of suicidal ideations or suicidal attempt (Option B): Strong indication for ECT, especially when urgent response is needed

Psychomotor agitation (Option D): Indicative of severe depression, often responds well to ECT

Key Takeaways:

  • ECT is best for severe, psychotic, or suicidal depression
  • Somatic symptom-predominant depression shows poor response to ECT

questions.text:
A 35-year-old housewife presented to the clinic with complaints of feeling low and disinterested in performing routine tasks throughout the day, decreased sleep, decreased appetite and feeling fatigued most of the day since last year. However, over the last 20 days, without any evident stressor, she started feeling extremely low, worthless as a human being, and could no longer see any hope in future. Often, she thought of ending her life and even planned to do so by consuming sleeping pills or jumping in a river. Regarding her management,
1. Electroconvulsive therapy is the best option according to her symptoms
2. Electroconvulsive therapy should only be used if the patient does not respond to psychotropics
3. Parenteral administration of ketamine can also be helpful
4. The patient should be managed after in-door admission
5. Treating her with a single antidepressant is usually enough even if suicidal ideations and planning are persistent
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient meets criteria for Major Depressive Disorder, Severe, with active suicidal ideation and planning
  • Statement 1 is TRUE: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a first-line option in severe depression with suicidal intent
  • Statement 2 is FALSE: ECT does not require prior failure of psychotropic medications; it can be used immediately if clinically indicated
  • Statement 3 is TRUE: Parenteral ketamine has shown rapid antidepressant effects, especially in acute suicidality
  • Statement 4 is TRUE: Due to suicidal risk, inpatient (indoor) admission is necessary for close monitoring and safety
  • Statement 5 is FALSE: A single antidepressant is usually not sufficient in the presence of persistent suicidal ideation; may require augmentation or somatic treatments

Key Takeaways:

  • ECT is first-line in suicidal, severe depression
  • Ketamine is effective for the acute relief of suicidal ideation
  • Admission is crucial in high-risk depressive episodes

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male diagnosed with psychosis and violent behavior is admitted for management in a psychiatric care facility. Which of the following factors should be kept in mind while planning for Electroconvulsive therapy in this patient?
1.Prior response to Electroconvulsive therapy should be considered
2. Pre-anesthetic workup is essential
3. Diabetes, even though well-controlled with oral hypoglycemics, is a contraindication for the Electroconvulsive therapy procedure
4. Advanced age, more than 35 years, is a contraindication for this procedure
5. Brain imaging should compulsorily be done before an Electroconvulsive procedure
6. Informed consent of both the patient and the caregiver is essential
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Statement 1 is TRUE: Prior response to ECT is an important factor in planning further treatment and predicts the likelihood of success
  • Statement 2 is TRUE: A pre-anesthetic workup is essential to ensure the patient's safety during ECT under anesthesia
  • Statement 3 is FALSE: Well-controlled diabetes is not a contraindication for ECT
  • Statement 4 is FALSE: Age over 35 is not a contraindication; ECT is safe and effective in elderly patients
  • Statement 5 is FALSE: Brain imaging is not mandatory unless there is clinical suspicion of intracranial pathology
  • Statement 6 is TRUE: Informed consent is required from both the patient and the caregiver, especially under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017

Key Takeaways:

  • Prior ECT response, anesthetic fitness, and informed consent are essential for planning
  • Controlled comorbidities and age are not contraindications
  • Neuroimaging is not mandatory unless clinically indicated

choices.text: Benzodiazepines
Lithium
Both
None

questions.text: A manic patient with severe symptoms has been admitted for electroconvulsive therapy. Which of the following psychotropics should be withheld before giving ECT in this patient due to possible interference with the induction of seizures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Benzodiazepines have anticonvulsant properties that can interfere with seizure induction, thereby reducing ECT efficacy; hence, they should be discontinued before ECT
  • Lithium increases the risk of prolonged seizures and postictal delirium, and is therefore also recommended to be withheld before ECT.
  • Both medications can compromise the safety and effectiveness of the ECT procedure.

Explanation of other options:

Benzodiazepines (Option A): True, but incomplete; lithium also needs to be withdrawn

Lithium (Option B): True, but benzodiazepines also interfere.

None (Option D): Incorrect; both medications should be withdrawn before ECT

Key Takeaways:

  • Benzodiazepines impair seizure induction due to anticonvulsant effects
  • Lithium increases the risk of delirium and prolonged seizures
  • Both should be withheld before initiating ECT

choices.text: Electroconvulsive therapy causes irreversible brain damage.
Electroconvulsive therapy cannot be given to childbearing age women, as it can cause hormonal imbalance.
Electroconvulsive therapy is a barbaric procedure as portrayed in movies, and hence traumatic to undergo
All the above

questions.text: Parents of a 21-year-old girl, who presented with severe manic symptoms, are advised about the administration of four to five sessions of electroconvulsive therapy to their daughter by their treating psychiatrist. But the parents are quite sceptical about the procedure. Which of the following general myths about electroconvulsive therapy needs to be addressed with her parents?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ECT causes irreversible brain damage is a myth. In reality, cognitive effects are transient and reversible; there is no evidence of permanent brain damage.
  • ECT cannot be given in childbearing age as it can cause a hormonal imbalance is a myth. In reality, ECT is safe during reproductive years and pregnancy and does not cause hormonal disturbances
  • ECT is a barbaric procedure as portrayed in movies, and hence, traumatic to undergo is a myth. In reality, modern ECT is a controlled medical procedure, done under general anesthesia, muscle relaxants, and close monitoring

Key Takeaways:

  • ECT is effective, safe, and medically regulated
  • Common myths about ECT are based on misinformation and stigma
  • Educating caregivers improves acceptance and treatment outcomes

choices.text: ECT-induced amnesia is irreversible
Both retrograde and anterograde amnesia may occur
Autobiographical memories are usually lost
All of the above

questions.text: A severely depressed patient, having undergone six sessions of Electroconvulsive therapy, complains of memory loss following the procedure. Which of the following is false about ECT-induced amnesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ECT-induced amnesia is irreversible and false. In reality, memory impairment is usually temporary, with most patients returning to baseline cognitive function within 6 months.
  • Both retrograde and anterograde amnesia may occur; patients may forget past events and have difficulty forming new memories during treatment.
  • Autobiographical memories are usually lost is true, especially for events close to the time of treatment, but recovery is often gradual and partial.

Key Takeaways:

  • ECT-related amnesia is generally temporary
  • Both types of memory (retrograde and anterograde) can be affected
  • Long-term brain damage is not supported by evidence

questions.text: Which of the following is true about electrode placement in Electroconvulsive therapy in the image depicted below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Image A shows bifronto-temporal electrode placement, which is the most historically and commonly practiced method in ECT due to its high efficacy and technical ease
  • Though efficacious, this placement is also associated with higher cognitive side effects, especially anterograde and retrograde amnesia.

Explanation of other options:

Electrode placement as shown in Image B causes maximum cognitive side-effects as compared to others (Option B): False; Image B shows unilateral placement, which causes fewer cognitive side effects than bifronto-temporal

Electrode placement as shown in Image C has a relatively lower seizure threshold (Option C): False; bifrontal placement (Image C) has a higher seizure threshold.

Handedness should usually be considered for the electrode placement shown in Image B (Option D): False; handedness is not a routine factor in determining unilateral electrode placement

Key Takeaways:

  • Bifronto-temporal (Image A) is most widely used, but carries more cognitive side effects
  • Unilateral placement (Image B) has less cognitive impact
  • Handedness is not a major factor in the electrode placement decision

choices.text: It is an invasive procedure
It involves using magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain
Repetitive TMS is a useful treatment in refractory cases of OCD
ECT is preferred over TMS in treatment-resistant cases of depression

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Transcranial magnetic stimulation(TMS)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • TMS (Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation) is a non-invasive brain stimulation technique that uses magnetic fields to stimulate specific areas of the cerebral cortex
  • It is painless, requires no anesthesia, and is often used in outpatient settings
  • Repetitive TMS (rTMS) has demonstrated efficacy in treatment-resistant OCD and depression, but ECT remains the gold standard in severe, refractory depression.

Explanation of other options:

It involves using magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain (Option B): True; this is the core mechanism of TMS.

Repetitive TMS is a useful treatment in refractory cases of OCD (Option C): True; approved for adjunctive treatment.

ECT is preferred over TMS in treatment-resistant cases of depression (Option D): True; ECT is more effective in severe or life-threatening cases

Key Takeaways:

  • TMS is non-invasive, unlike ECT, which is a more intense procedure requiring anesthesia
  • rTMS is beneficial in OCD and depression, but ECT remains first-line for severe cases
  • Magnetic field stimulation is the basis of TMS technology
